Title: ECMiner™ includes Input Node, Preprocessing Node, Chart Node, Modeling Node, Output Node, and Model Evaluation Node.
All nodes in ECMiner™ have properties essential for performing their tasks. Properties are fundamentally composed of a property name and a property value. For example, the File Reader Node requires a property that specifies which file to read, represented by the property name (File Path) and the property value.

Context:
This table is about the section * Wild Card. 
Title: The meanings of the four wildcards are defined as follows: 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = wildcard; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 2, column 1 = *; row 2, column 2 = The asterisk (*) represents any string. For example, "A*" denotes all variable names starting with A, and "*B" denotes all variable names ending with B.; row 3, column 1 = ?; row 3, column 2 = The question mark (?) represents any single character. For example, "A??B" denotes a four-character variable name that starts with A and ends with B.; row 4, column 1 = #; row 4, column 2 = The pound sign (#) represents any single digit. For example, "A##B" denotes a variable name that starts with A, has two digits (0-9) in between, and ends with B.; row 5, column 1 = $; row 5, column 2 = The dollar sign ($) represents any single character that is not a digit. For example, "A$$B" denotes a variable name that starts with A, has two non-digit characters in between, and ends with B.
table_html:
wildcard Description
* The asterisk (*) represents any string. For example, "A*" denotes all variable names starting with A, and "*B" denotes all variable names ending with B.
? The question mark (?) represents any single character. For example, "A??B" denotes a four-character variable name that starts with A and ends with B.
# The pound sign (#) represents any single digit. For example, "A##B" denotes a variable name that starts with A, has two digits (0-9) in between, and ends with B.
$ The dollar sign ($) represents any single character that is not a digit. For example, "A$$B" denotes a variable name that starts with A, has two non-digit characters in between, and ends with B.
NOTE: Precautions for using wild cards. Entering "*" in the variable name condition represents all variable names. To select variables that include "ABC" in their names, enter "*ABC*". Entering "ABC" without asterisks will select variables named exactly "ABC". Spaces are treated as characters. Entering "* ABC *" will find variable names that include " ABC ", not just "ABC".

table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
DB Connection Select the driver Specifies the appropriate OLEDB driver for the type of database you want to connect to. Required
DB Server Connection Information Enter appropriate information to identify the database. For SQL server, enter the IP address of the database server. For Oracle, enter the TNS name.
User Name Enter the username to access the database.
Password Enter the password to access the database.
Partial Read Partial Read Method Specifies the method for partially reading the database. Required Read All, From the beginning, Random Sampling
Partial Read Arguments With 'From the beginning', the argument is the number of observations. With 'Random Sampling', it is the percentage of observations.
Table Fetch DB Information Retrieve information about the database’s schema, tables, views, and other elements from the connected database. button
Use Query Specify whether to fetch data using a query. Yes, No
Table Type Select the database schema to be listed in the table attribute. It supports tables and views. All, Table, View
Schema Display list of table spaces or owners.
Table Specifies the table from which to import the data.
Query Edit Query Activated when the ‘Use Query’ attribute is set to 'Yes'. Popping up the query editor, edit, load, and save the query. button
Check Query Check current inputted query. Click the ‘Edit Query’ button to modify it.
Variable Information Variable Information Displays the variable name and data type

Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
File File Path Specifies the path for the file. Required
Reload Files Re-import the data if the file was not read properly or you modified the file. button
Preview View a portion of the specified file.
Partial Read Partial Read Method Specifies the method for partially reading the database. Required Read All, From the beginning, Random Sampling
Partial Read Arguments With 'From the beginning', the argument is the number of observations. With 'Random Sampling', it is the percentage of observations.
Selection options Is first row Variable names Set to 'Yes’, if the first row is ‘Variable name’. If set to 'No' even when the first row contains variable names, all variable types may be set as strings. Auto. Yes, No
Delimiter Select the type of delimiter. Supported delimiters are tab, space, bar, comma, semicolon, and colon. To use a different delimiter, select the 'Other' option. Required (tab), '|', (Space), ',', ';', ':', (Other)
Other Delimiter Set other delimiters in case the property of a delimiter is (Other).
Test has grouping symbols Specify whether to remove quotation marks from string data that contains them. Ex: “ABC" ABC Yes, No
Variable Information Variable Information Displays the variable name and data type

table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
File File Path Specifies the path for the file. Required
Reload Files Re-import the data if the file was not read properly or you modified the file. button
Preview View a portion of the specified file.
Partial Read Partial Read Method Specifies the method for partially reading the database. Required Read All, From the beginning, Random Sampling
Partial Read Arguments With 'From the beginning', the argument is the number of observations. With 'Random Sampling', it is the percentage of observations.
Selection options Is first row Variable names Set to 'Yes’, if the first row is ‘Variable name’. If set to 'No' even when the first row contains variable names, all variable types may be set as strings. Auto. Yes, No
Delimiter Select the type of delimiter. Supported delimiters are tab, space, bar, comma, semicolon, and colon. To use a different delimiter, select the 'Other' option. Required (tab), '|', (Space), ',', ';', ':', (Other)
Other Delimiter Set other delimiters in case the property of a delimiter is (Other).
Test has grouping symbols Specify whether to remove quotation marks from string data that contains them. Ex: “ABC" ABC Yes, No
Variable Information Variable Information Displays the variable name and data type

table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
File Variable Matching Method Two options: " Variable Order", " Variable Name". Variable Order Consider variables with the same order as identical. Variable Name Consider variables with the same name as identical. Required Variable Order Variable Name
File Path Specifies the path for the file.
File type Use an asterisk (*) as a prefix or suffix to specify and distinguish the file type. If the data files are named "test1, test2, ..." enter "test*". For files named "1test, 2test, ..." enter "*test".
Variable Information Variable Information Displays the variable name and data type to be read.
NOTE: In the 'Variable Matching Method', if the 'Variable Name' option is selected and the variables in the input datasets do not match, the unmatched datasets will be filled with blank spaces.

File Path Specifies the path for the file.
File type Use an asterisk (*) as a prefix or suffix to specify and distinguish the file type. If the data files are named "test1, test2, ..." enter "test*". For files named "1test, 2test, ..." enter "*test".
Variable Information Variable Information Displays the variable name and data type to be read.

Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Standardized variables Status Choose whether to create a standardized variable To create a new variable for the standardized, select 'Yes'
Suffix Specify the suffix string for a derived standardized variable
Standardization Mean Specify the mean value for the standardized variable
Standardization Standard Deviation Specify the standard deviation for the standardized variable
Maximum correction Select this option if you want the maximum value of the generated standardized variables
Relative ratio variable Creation status Specify whether to create relative ratio variables. Conditionally Required
Suffix Specify the string to append to the generated relative ratio variables.
Select Reference Variable Reference Variable If no variable is specified, calculations are performed for each record. If a variable is specified, calculations are performed for each category of the specified reference variable. The reference variable must be categorical. Optional Refer to the Usage.
Variables to Transform Variable to Transform Select the variables to transform, which must be continuous. Required Refer to the Usage.

Context:
This table is about the section 3.2 Preprocessing Node > 3.2.6 Merge Node > [image:rId80]. 
Title: The Data Source interface displays data sets. Select a data set with the highest priority for merging. When merging two datasets, the data source with the highest priority serves as the primary base.
To set the key field for merging, select the variable in the list of Possible Key Fields and then it goes to Selected Key Fields. Use the buttons in the center to select or deselect key fields
Data Source to Include is activated when Merge Method is set to Partial Outer Join, which returns only the selected data sources.

table_html:
Merge Method Description Note
Inner Join Keeps only rows where ‘key variable’ matches in both data sets
Outer Join Keeps all rows from both datasets, adding NaN or nulls where no match is found.
Partial Outer Join Keep all rows from the data set with the highest priority and add matched rows from the second data set. You must specify the data sources to include.
Anti-Join Adds rows with non-matching key value from the data sources to the new data source

Context:
This table is about the section 3.2 Preprocessing Node > 3.2.11 Image Processing Node > Operation Principle of Filters. 
Title: Operation Principle of Filters 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Category; row 1, column 2 = Filter; row 1, column 3 = Filter; row 1, column 4 = Property; row 1, column 5 = Property; row 2, column 1 = ; row 2, column 2 = Name; row 2, column 3 = Description; row 2, column 4 = Name; row 2, column 5 = Description; row 3, column 1 = Filter Correction; row 3, column 2 = Blur; row 3, column 3 = Blur the input image.; row 3, column 4 = Filter Size; row 3, column 5 = Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13; row 4, column 1 = ; row 4, column 2 = Emboss; row 4, column 3 = Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface.; row 4, column 4 = Filter Type; row 4, column 5 = Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast; row 5, column 1 = ; row 5, column 2 = Soften; row 5, column 3 = Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version.; row 5, column 4 = Filter Type; row 5, column 5 = Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
table_html:
Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)

table_html:
Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7

Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.

It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7

Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)

Kernel Size (Default value: 3)

Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE

Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4

table_html:
Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)
PARAM2 value (Default value: 100)
Minimum radius value (Default value: 10)
Maximum radius value (Default value: 0)
Use of blur Choose from Use, Not Use
Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Grayscale Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Color Extraction Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen. Color type Choose from Red, Green, Blue
Contours Detection Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity. Use of Threshold Choose from Use, Not Use
Threshold (Default value: 127)
Contour Detection Mode Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Contour Approximation Method Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
Output Method Choose from Origin,
Flood Fill If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color. Staring X (Default value: 0)
Staring Y (Default value: 0)
Low Diff (Default value: 5)
High Diff (Default value: 5)
Color Choose one of 13 colors.
Histogram Equalization Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels. Histogram Method Choosing from Smoothing, Stretching, Sliding
Sliding Value (Default value: 0)
Fourier Transform The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations. Transformation Method Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Change Detection Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Threshold (Default value: 50)
Noise Removal Filter Choose from 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
Change Detection (CNN) Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Patch size (Default value: 5)
Threshold (Default value: 50)
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
