table_html:
Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)
PARAM2 value (Default value: 100)
Minimum radius value (Default value: 10)
Maximum radius value (Default value: 0)
Use of blur Choose from Use, Not Use
Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Grayscale Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Color Extraction Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen. Color type Choose from Red, Green, Blue
Contours Detection Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity. Use of Threshold Choose from Use, Not Use
Threshold (Default value: 127)
Contour Detection Mode Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Contour Approximation Method Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
Output Method Choose from Origin,
Flood Fill If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color. Staring X (Default value: 0)
Staring Y (Default value: 0)
Low Diff (Default value: 5)
High Diff (Default value: 5)
Color Choose one of 13 colors.
Histogram Equalization Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels. Histogram Method Choosing from Smoothing, Stretching, Sliding
Sliding Value (Default value: 0)
Fourier Transform The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations. Transformation Method Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Change Detection Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Threshold (Default value: 50)
Noise Removal Filter Choose from 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
Change Detection (CNN) Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Patch size (Default value: 5)
Threshold (Default value: 50)
View Changes Only Choose from true, false

table_html:
Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)
PARAM2 value (Default value: 100)
Minimum radius value (Default value: 10)
Maximum radius value (Default value: 0)
Use of blur Choose from Use, Not Use
Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Grayscale Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Color Extraction Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen. Color type Choose from Red, Green, Blue
Contours Detection Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity. Use of Threshold Choose from Use, Not Use
Threshold (Default value: 127)
Contour Detection Mode Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Contour Approximation Method Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
Output Method Choose from Origin,
Flood Fill If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color. Staring X (Default value: 0)
Staring Y (Default value: 0)
Low Diff (Default value: 5)
High Diff (Default value: 5)
Color Choose one of 13 colors.
Histogram Equalization Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels. Histogram Method Choosing from Smoothing, Stretching, Sliding
Sliding Value (Default value: 0)
Fourier Transform The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations. Transformation Method Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Change Detection Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Threshold (Default value: 50)
Noise Removal Filter Choose from 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
Change Detection (CNN) Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Patch size (Default value: 5)
Threshold (Default value: 50)
View Changes Only Choose from true, false

Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)
Corner Detection Minimum Eigenvalue A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
Harris A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Block Size (Default value: 2)
k (Default value: 0.04)
Minimum Detection Value Ratio (Default value: 0.1)
GFTT(Good Features to Track) A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Block Size (Default value: 3)
Detection Limit Ratio (Default value: 0.01)
Detection Count Limit (Default value: 25)
Minimum Distance Between Detections (Default value: 3)
FAST A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed. Result Image Format Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Threshold (Default value: 10)
Non-Maximum partition suppression Choose from Use, Not Used
Morphology Erosion Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Dilation Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Opening Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Closing Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Binary Threshold (Default value: 100)
Draw Borders Choose from Yes, No
Border Thickness (Default value: 3.0)
R Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
G Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
B Upper Limit (Default value: 255)
Top Hat Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
TOP HAT Type Choose from WHITE, BLACK
Gradient Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate. Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Smoothing This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video Kernel Shape Choose from RECT, CROSS, ELLIPSE
Kernel Size (Default value: 3)
Geometry Rotation Rotate the image counterclockwise. Rotation angle 0~360 degrees
Scaling Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size. Interpolation Method Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Scaling Size (Default value: 1.0)
Super Resolution Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image. Super Resolution Method Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Scaling Size Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)
PARAM2 value (Default value: 100)
Minimum radius value (Default value: 10)
Maximum radius value (Default value: 0)
Use of blur Choose from Use, Not Use
Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Grayscale Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Color Extraction Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen. Color type Choose from Red, Green, Blue
Contours Detection Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity. Use of Threshold Choose from Use, Not Use
Threshold (Default value: 127)
Contour Detection Mode Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Contour Approximation Method Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
Output Method Choose from Origin,
Flood Fill If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color. Staring X (Default value: 0)
Staring Y (Default value: 0)
Low Diff (Default value: 5)
High Diff (Default value: 5)
Color Choose one of 13 colors.
Histogram Equalization Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels. Histogram Method Choosing from Smoothing, Stretching, Sliding
Sliding Value (Default value: 0)
Fourier Transform The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations. Transformation Method Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Change Detection Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Threshold (Default value: 50)
Noise Removal Filter Choose from 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
Change Detection (CNN) Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Patch size (Default value: 5)
Threshold (Default value: 50)
View Changes Only Choose from true, false

Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7

Category Filter Property
Name Description Name Description
Filter Correction Blur Blur the input image. Filter Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Emboss Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface. Filter Type Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Soften Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version. Filter Type Choose from Smoothly1,2,3 etc.
Sharpen Enhance the clarity of the input image. Mask type: Choose from Sh
Unsharp Filter Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9
Blur Reduction Rate (%) (Default value: 10.0)
Median Filter Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha-Trimmed Mean Filter Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Alpha Value
MinMax Filter Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Maximum value Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Gaussian Smoothing Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values. Mask Size Sigma: (Default value: 1.0)
Edge Detection Gradient Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Sobel Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Scharr Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Prewitt Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Frei-Chen Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Roberts Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed. Mask Direction Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Laplacian Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values. Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Threshold1 (Default value: 0.2)
Threshold2 (Default value: 0.8)

The "Fields" column lists the variables that will be added when the node is executed. As shown in the image, variables from "data source A~C" are mapped to the "Fields" variables.

Title: Node Properties 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Property group; row 1, column 2 = Property Name; row 1, column 3 = Description; row 1, column 4 = Misc.; row 1, column 5 = Note; row 2, column 1 = Selection options; row 2, column 2 = Sampling method; row 2, column 3 = Select sampling method.; row 2, column 4 = Required; row 2, column 5 = Random Sampling, Systematic Sampling, Stratified Sampling, From the beginning, Stratified Sampling (Equal Partition); row 3, column 1 = ; row 3, column 2 = Selection status; row 3, column 3 = Specify whether you want to use or exclude the extracted data.; row 3, column 4 = ; row 3, column 5 = Select, Exclusion; row 4, column 1 = ; row 4, column 2 = Discrete Variable; row 4, column 3 = Select the discrete variable to be used as the basis for stratified sampling.; row 4, column 4 = ; row 4, column 5 = ; row 5, column 1 = Sample size; row 5, column 2 = Sample size method; row 5, column 3 = Specify the method for determining the sample size.; row 5, column 4 = Required; row 5, column 5 = Percentage, Count.
table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Selection options Sampling method Select sampling method. Required Random Sampling, Systematic Sampling, Stratified Sampling, From the beginning, Stratified Sampling (Equal Partition)
Selection status Specify whether you want to use or exclude the extracted data. Select, Exclusion
Discrete Variable Select the discrete variable to be used as the basis for stratified sampling.
Sample size Sample size method Specify the method for determining the sample size. Required Percentage, Count.
Sample size (percentage) Set the Percentage of samples for sampling. If the calculated sample count is not an integer, it is roundest to integer real numbers from 0 to 100
Sample size (Count) Set the number(count) of samples for sampling integer
NOTE: Description of the sampling method. Random Extraction: Extract data randomly using tools such as random number tables. Hierarchy Extraction: Order every member of the population, extract one sample randomly, and then extract subsequent samples at fixed intervals. (Note: Only up to 50% of the total data can be sampled. Additionally, if the calculated sampling interval is not an integer, it is rounded to the nearest integer.) Stratified Sampling: Dividing the population into homogeneous subgroups and then randomly sampling from these subgroups based on their sizes.

Rows: row 1, column 1 = NOTE: Regular expressions serve as templates to match specific patterns and search terms in data. They are made up of literals (pure letters or numbers), metacharacters (which represent types of characters or character groups), and escape sequences. Literal: When only literals are used, without metacharacters and escapes, their representation is identical to the lemma notation.Example) "Regular expression name John Doe" extracts "John Doe" as a morpheme and assigns it the part of speech "name." Single Character Metacharacters [table:t727_n1] Composite character-type metacharacters [table:t727_n2] Escaping: Unmentioned non-printable characters in metacharacters are also specified by escapes. [table:t727_n3]
table_html: NOTE: Regular expressions serve as templates to match specific patterns and search terms in data. They are made up of literals (pure letters or numbers), metacharacters (which represent types of characters or character groups), and escape sequences. Literal: When only literals are used, without metacharacters and escapes, their representation is identical to the lemma notation.Example) "Regular expression name John Doe" extracts "John Doe" as a morpheme and assigns it the part of speech "name." Single Character Metacharacters [table:t727_n1] Composite character-type metacharacters [table:t727_n2] Escaping: Unmentioned non-printable characters in metacharacters are also specified by escapes. [table:t727_n3]

Context:
This table is about the section 3.2 Preprocessing Node > 3.2.28 Import Python Node > Node Properties. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Metacharacters; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Examples; row 2, column 1 = *; row 2, column 2 = Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions.; row 2, column 3 = "zo*" finds "z" and "zoo."; row 3, column 1 = +; row 3, column 2 = Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions.; row 3, column 3 = "zo+" finds "zo" and "zoo" but not "z."; row 4, column 1 = ?; row 4, column 2 = Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible.; row 4, column 3 = zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."; row 5, column 1 = ^; row 5, column 2 = Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters.; row 5, column 3 = "^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
table_html:
Metacharacters Description Examples
* Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions. "zo*" finds "z" and "zoo."
+ Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. "zo+" finds "zo" and "zoo" but not "z."
? Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible. zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."
^ Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters. "^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
$ Locates positions at the end of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions before `\n` or `\r`. "\d{3}$" finds three digits at the end of the searched string.
. Find all single characters except the newline character `\n`. To find all characters, including `\n`, patterns like `[\s\S]` are used. "a.c" finds "abc," "a1c," and "a-c."
[] Square brackets mark the beginning and end of a set, grouping one or more individual characters into a list. [1-4] finds "1", "2", "3", or "4". [^aAeEiIoOuU] finds any character that is not a vowel.
{} Quantifiers mark the start and end of an expression and specify the number of times to repeat the sequence when the number of characters cannot be predefined. a{2,3} finds "aa" and "aaa".
() Parentheses mark the beginning and end of a subexpression, which can be stored for later use. A(\d) finds anything from "A0" to "A9", storing the digit for later use.
| The pipe symbol represents a choice between two or more items. z|food finds either "z" or "food". (z|f)ood finds "zood" or "food".
/ Slashes mark the beginning and end of a literal regular expression pattern. After the second slash, a single character flag can be added to specify search behavior. /abc/gi is a literal regular expression that finds "abc". The 'g' flag specifies finding all occurrences of the pattern, and the 'i' flag specifies ignoring case during the search.
\ The following character is indicated as a special character, literal, or octal escape. To search for a single character meta character, you must escape the character. \n finds a newline character. \( finds "(". \\ finds "\". \+ finds "+".

* Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions. "zo*" finds "z" and "zoo."
+ Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. "zo+" finds "zo" and "zoo" but not "z."
? Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible. zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."
^ Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters. "^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
$ Locates positions at the end of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions before `\n` or `\r`. "\d{3}$" finds three digits at the end of the searched string.
. Find all single characters except the newline character `\n`. To find all characters, including `\n`, patterns like `[\s\S]` are used. "a.c" finds "abc," "a1c," and "a-c."
[] Square brackets mark the beginning and end of a set, grouping one or more individual characters into a list. [1-4] finds "1", "2", "3", or "4". [^aAeEiIoOuU] finds any character that is not a vowel.
{} Quantifiers mark the start and end of an expression and specify the number of times to repeat the sequence when the number of characters cannot be predefined. a{2,3} finds "aa" and "aaa".
() Parentheses mark the beginning and end of a subexpression, which can be stored for later use. A(\d) finds anything from "A0" to "A9", storing the digit for later use.
| The pipe symbol represents a choice between two or more items. z|food finds either "z" or "food". (z|f)ood finds "zood" or "food".
/ Slashes mark the beginning and end of a literal regular expression pattern. After the second slash, a single character flag can be added to specify search behavior. /abc/gi is a literal regular expression that finds "abc". The 'g' flag specifies finding all occurrences of the pattern, and the 'i' flag specifies ignoring case during the search.
\ The following character is indicated as a special character, literal, or octal escape. To search for a single character meta character, you must escape the character. \n finds a newline character. \( finds "(". \\ finds "\". \+ finds "+".

table_html:
Metacharacters Description Example
\b Finds word boundaries, which are positions between a word and a space. "er\b" finds "er" in "never" but not in "verb."
\B Finds non-word boundaries. "er\B" finds "er" in "verb" but not in "never."
\d Finds digits. Same as [0-9]. When the searched string is "12 345," "\d{2}" finds "12" and "34." "\d" finds "1," "2," "3," "4," or "5."
\D Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. "\D+" finds "abc" and " def" in "abc123 def."
\w Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
\W Finds all characters except A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and underscores. Same as [^A-Za-z0-9_]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
[xyz] It is a character set. Finds any one of the specified characters. "[abc]" finds "a" in "plain."
[^xyz] It is a negated character set. Finds any characters not specified. "[^abc]" finds "p," "l," "i," and "n" in "plain."
-a[z] It is a character range. Finds characters within a specified range. "[a-z]" finds lowercase English letters from "a" to "z."
[^a-z] It is a negated character range. Finds any characters not within the specified range. "[^a-z]" finds all characters that are not in the range "a" to "z."
{n} Finds exactly n occurrences, where n is an integer. "o{2}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds the two "o"s in "food."
{n,} Finds at least n occurrences, where n is an integer. "*" is equivalent to {0,}. "+" is equivalent to {1,}. "o{2,}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds all the "o"s in "foooood."
{n,m} Finds at least n and at most m occurrences, where n and m are integers, and n is less than or equal to m. There should be no space between the comma and the numbers. "?" is equivalent to {0,1}. When the searched string is "1234567," "\d{1,3}" finds "123," "456," and "7."
(pattern) Finds a pattern and stores the matching items. To find the parenthesis characters ( ), use "\(" or "\)". "(Chapter|Section) [1-9]" finds "Chapter 5" and stores "Chapter" for later use.
(?:pattern) Finds a pattern but does not store the matches. That is, the matches are not saved for later use. This is useful when combining parts of the pattern with the "or" character (|). "industr(?:y|ies)" is the same as industry|industries.
(?=pattern) It is a positive lookahead. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. ^(?=.*\d).{4,8}$ ensures a password is between 4-8 characters and includes at least one digit. Within the pattern, ".*\d" finds any number of characters followed by a digit. When the searched string is "abc3qr," it matches "abc3." ".{4,8}" starts from the front, not the back of the match, finding 4-8 characters. This matches "abc3qr." "^" and "$" specify positions at the start and end of the searched string. This ensures that if there are characters outside the matched string, it does not count as a match.
(?!pattern) It is a negative lookahead. It finds search strings that do not match the pattern. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. "\b(?!th)\w+\b" finds words that do not start with "th." Within the pattern, "\b" finds word boundaries. When the searched string is " quick," it matches the first space. "(?!th)" finds strings that are not "th," matching "qu." "\w+" searches for a word from the front of the match. This matches "quick."
\cx Finds control characters marked with "x". The value of "x" must be within the range of A-Z or a-z. If not, "c" is considered as the literal character "c". "\cM" finds the Ctrl+M or carriage return character.
\xn Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "\x41" finds "A". "n" must be exactly two digits, so "\x041" is like writing "\x04" followed by "1".
\num Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "(.)\1" finds two consecutive identical characters.
\n Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "n" captured subexpressions before "\n", then "n" is a backreference indicating additional repetitions of the subexpression. If "n" is an octal (0-7) and there are not enough preceding captures, then "n" is an octal escape value. "(\d)\1" finds two consecutive identical digits.
\nm Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "nm" captured subexpressions before "\nm", then "nm" is a backreference. If there are "n" captures before "\nm" and a literal "m" follows, then "n" is a backreference followed by literal "m". If none of these conditions are met, "\nm" finds the octal escape value "nm", assuming "n" and "m" are octal (0-7). "\11" finds the tab character.
\nml Finds the octal escape value "nml" where "n" is an octal (0-3) and "m" and "l" are octals (0-7). "\011" finds the tab character.
\un Finds "n", where "n" is a Unicode character represented by a four-digit hexadecimal "\u00A9" finds the copyright symbol (©).

table_html:
Metacharacters Description Example
\b Finds word boundaries, which are positions between a word and a space. "er\b" finds "er" in "never" but not in "verb."
\B Finds non-word boundaries. "er\B" finds "er" in "verb" but not in "never."
\d Finds digits. Same as [0-9]. When the searched string is "12 345," "\d{2}" finds "12" and "34." "\d" finds "1," "2," "3," "4," or "5."
\D Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. "\D+" finds "abc" and " def" in "abc123 def."
\w Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
\W Finds all characters except A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and underscores. Same as [^A-Za-z0-9_]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
[xyz] It is a character set. Finds any one of the specified characters. "[abc]" finds "a" in "plain."
[^xyz] It is a negated character set. Finds any characters not specified. "[^abc]" finds "p," "l," "i," and "n" in "plain."
-a[z] It is a character range. Finds characters within a specified range. "[a-z]" finds lowercase English letters from "a" to "z."
[^a-z] It is a negated character range. Finds any characters not within the specified range. "[^a-z]" finds all characters that are not in the range "a" to "z."
{n} Finds exactly n occurrences, where n is an integer. "o{2}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds the two "o"s in "food."
{n,} Finds at least n occurrences, where n is an integer. "*" is equivalent to {0,}. "+" is equivalent to {1,}. "o{2,}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds all the "o"s in "foooood."
{n,m} Finds at least n and at most m occurrences, where n and m are integers, and n is less than or equal to m. There should be no space between the comma and the numbers. "?" is equivalent to {0,1}. When the searched string is "1234567," "\d{1,3}" finds "123," "456," and "7."
(pattern) Finds a pattern and stores the matching items. To find the parenthesis characters ( ), use "\(" or "\)". "(Chapter|Section) [1-9]" finds "Chapter 5" and stores "Chapter" for later use.
(?:pattern) Finds a pattern but does not store the matches. That is, the matches are not saved for later use. This is useful when combining parts of the pattern with the "or" character (|). "industr(?:y|ies)" is the same as industry|industries.
(?=pattern) It is a positive lookahead. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. ^(?=.*\d).{4,8}$ ensures a password is between 4-8 characters and includes at least one digit. Within the pattern, ".*\d" finds any number of characters followed by a digit. When the searched string is "abc3qr," it matches "abc3." ".{4,8}" starts from the front, not the back of the match, finding 4-8 characters. This matches "abc3qr." "^" and "$" specify positions at the start and end of the searched string. This ensures that if there are characters outside the matched string, it does not count as a match.
(?!pattern) It is a negative lookahead. It finds search strings that do not match the pattern. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. "\b(?!th)\w+\b" finds words that do not start with "th." Within the pattern, "\b" finds word boundaries. When the searched string is " quick," it matches the first space. "(?!th)" finds strings that are not "th," matching "qu." "\w+" searches for a word from the front of the match. This matches "quick."
\cx Finds control characters marked with "x". The value of "x" must be within the range of A-Z or a-z. If not, "c" is considered as the literal character "c". "\cM" finds the Ctrl+M or carriage return character.
\xn Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "\x41" finds "A". "n" must be exactly two digits, so "\x041" is like writing "\x04" followed by "1".
\num Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "(.)\1" finds two consecutive identical characters.
\n Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "n" captured subexpressions before "\n", then "n" is a backreference indicating additional repetitions of the subexpression. If "n" is an octal (0-7) and there are not enough preceding captures, then "n" is an octal escape value. "(\d)\1" finds two consecutive identical digits.
\nm Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "nm" captured subexpressions before "\nm", then "nm" is a backreference. If there are "n" captures before "\nm" and a literal "m" follows, then "n" is a backreference followed by literal "m". If none of these conditions are met, "\nm" finds the octal escape value "nm", assuming "n" and "m" are octal (0-7). "\11" finds the tab character.
\nml Finds the octal escape value "nml" where "n" is an octal (0-3) and "m" and "l" are octals (0-7). "\011" finds the tab character.
\un Finds "n", where "n" is a Unicode character represented by a four-digit hexadecimal "\u00A9" finds the copyright symbol (©).

table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Chart options Bar Stack Specify the type of bar chart. (Disabled when the X-axis type is set to series index due to the nature of the Bar Chart.) Required None, Stacked, Stacked 100%
X-axis format Set X-axis type. Data Index: Data index values of the specified variables will be used for the X-axis. Series Index: The chart will be divided by series, which can be identified through the legend Required Data Index, Series Index
Add Used to plot multiple series on a single chart. Adds selected series. button
Delete Deletes last added series. button
Edit Removes unselected series. button
Series List Series #00 Variable Specify the variable to be displayed as a bar chart Required
Label Specify the variable to be used as the label. If the type of the specified variable is discrete, this property will be ignored
NOTE: The meaning of a Bar chart varies based on the variable type. If the variable is continuous, the x-value represents the data index and the y-value represents the corresponding variable value. If the variable is discrete (categorical), the x-value represents the category name and the y-value represents the frequency of data in that category.

Outlier Display Decide whether to display outlier on the chart. Required Yes, No

Context:

Title: Usage 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = [image:rId207]; row 1, column 2 = Specify the variables to be used for the X1-axis, X2-axis, and Y-axis in the Series List properties window. Options Specify Color pattern properties. Specify 3D Surface properties. Click the 'Add Series' button as many times as needed to add the required number of series NOTE The X1-axis and X2-axis correspond to the two-dimensional axes for the contour coordinates, while the Y-axis represents the height at each coordinate.
table_html: [image:rId207] Specify the variables to be used for the X1-axis, X2-axis, and Y-axis in the Series List properties window. Options Specify Color pattern properties. Specify 3D Surface properties. Click the 'Add Series' button as many times as needed to add the required number of series NOTE The X1-axis and X2-axis correspond to the two-dimensional axes for the contour coordinates, while the Y-axis represents the height at each coordinate.

Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Chart options 3D Surface Specify whether to display in 3D or in 2D. Required Yes, No
Add Used to plot multiple series on a single chart. Adds selected series. button
Delete Deletes last added series. button
Edit Removes unselected series. button
Series List Series #00 X1-Axis Specify the variable for the X1 axis (first position coordinate). Required
X2-Axis Specify the variable for the X2 axis (second position coordinate) Required
Y-Axis Specify the Y-axis variable, which represents the height. Required
Color pattern Specify the color pattern for the contours on the chart. Required Strongly, Weaken, Three Colors, Two Colors, Monochrome

Rows: row 1, column 1 = Property group; row 1, column 2 = Property Name; row 1, column 3 = Description; row 1, column 4 = Misc.; row 1, column 5 = Note; row 2, column 1 = Chart options; row 2, column 2 = Create Chart for Each Variable; row 2, column 3 = Plots multiple charts, one for each variable.; row 2, column 4 = Required; row 2, column 5 = Yes, No; row 3, column 1 = ; row 3, column 2 = Number of Charts in Row; row 3, column 3 = Specify the number of charts to be placed in each row.; row 3, column 4 = ; row 3, column 5 = Natural Number; row 4, column 1 = Group Variable Options; row 4, column 2 = Group Display; row 4, column 3 = Specify the method for displaying group-related variables in the data if such variables are present; row 4, column 4 = Required; row 4, column 5 = No grouping, Series separation, or Chart separation; row 5, column 1 = ; row 5, column 2 = Group Variable #1; row 5, column 3 = Select the first group variable.; row 5, column 4 = ; row 5, column 5 =
table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Chart options Create Chart for Each Variable Plots multiple charts, one for each variable. Required Yes, No
Number of Charts in Row Specify the number of charts to be placed in each row. Natural Number
Group Variable Options Group Display Specify the method for displaying group-related variables in the data if such variables are present Required No grouping, Series separation, or Chart separation
Group Variable #1 Select the first group variable.
Group Variable #2 Select the second group variable.
Group Variable #3 Select the third group variable
Group Variable #4 Select the fourth group variable.
Group Variable #5 Select the fifth group variable.
User-defined maximum/minimum Y-axis Decide whether to use manually specified Y-axis values. Required Yes, No
Y-axis minimum Minimum value of Y-axis Real Number
Y-axis maximum Maximum value of Y-axis Real Number
Interval Method Interval Method Specify the method for determining the data intervals of the specified continuous variable. Required Interval Width, Number of Intervals
Interval Width Enabled when the Interval method is set to interval Width. Calculates the number of data points within each specified interval and draws a histogram Real Number
Number of Intervals Enabled when the Interval method is set to number of sections. Divides the entire range into the specified number of intervals, calculates the number of data points within each interval, and draws a histogram Natural Number
Range Setting Auto-Configuration Determine whether to manually specify the minimum and maximum values for the range of the histogram Required Yes, No
Minimum Value Enabled when Auto-Configuration is set to No. Enter the minimum value for the range in which to draw the histogram. Real Number
Maximum Value Enabled when Auto-Configuration is set to No. Enter the maximum value for the range in which to draw the histogram. Real Number
Distribution Line Normal distribution curve Specify whether to include a normal distribution curve Required Yes, No
Select Variables Variable list Specify the variables to be plotted as a chart. Required

Chart form Chart form Select a charting method. Trend, Data, Box Plot, Distribution, Correlation
Chart options Display Regression Line When the chart form is Correlation, select whether or not to display rare lines. Yes, No Simple matrix diagram, X Y specified matrix diagram
Display Basic Statistics When the Chart form is Box Plot, select whether or not to display basic statistics. Yes, No
Display points/lines When the chart form is Trend or Data, select whether to display dots and lines on the chart. Yes, No
Outlier Display When the chart form is Box Plot, select whether or not to display outliers. Yes, No
Management Limits UCL When the chart form is Trend or Data, select the variable to display the upper limit. continuous variable
LCL When the chart form is Trend or Data, select the variable to display the low limit. continuous variable
Output Option Number of Charts in Row Specify the number of charts to be displayed in one row. Natural Number 1~10
Number of Charts within a Column Specify the number of charts to be displayed in one column. Natural Number 1~10

Chart division Variable List Specify the variables to be plotted a chart. Optional
Group Variable Variable List Specify the variables to be plotted a chart. Optional

Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Chart options Chart MA chart or EWMA chart. Required
Variable setting Variables Select variables. Required
Subgroup Size Size of the subgroup Required real type
Parameter estimation Using the population mean Decide whether to draw the chart using the population mean. Required Yes, No

NOTE: The weight option determines the influence of recent data points. Recent data points have a higher weight, while older data points have progressively lower weights.

Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Chart options Display method Points: Plot the data at each observation time as dots. Line: Draw a line connecting the values from before and after. Points with line: Plot the data as points at each observation time and connect them with lines. Required Points, Line, Points with line
Create Axis for Each Variable Specify whether to display the Y variable in separate charts for each variable or in a single combined chart. Required Yes, No
Separate Y-Axis for Each Variable When Separate Y-Axis for Each Variable is set to No, specify whether to use a separate Y axis or a single axis Yes, No
Time Scale Variable For Time Series Y, specify the time scale variable to use for the X-axis. Use the Data Index if a time scale variable does not exist.
Group Variable Options Group Display Specify how to display data groups. Optional Separate by Series, Color by category, Display as Label
Group Variable #1 Select the first group variable.
Group Variable #2 Select the second group variable.
Group Variable #3 Select the third group variable.
Group Variable #4 Select the fourth group variable.
Group Variable #5 Select the fifth group variable.
User-defined maximum/minimum Y-axis Decide whether to use manually specified Y-axis values. Required Yes, No
Y-axis minimum Minimum value of Y-axis Real Number
Y-axis maximum Maximum value of Y-axis Real Number
Select Variables Variable list Specify the variables to be plotted. Required
